We hope you can help in any way you can! With appreciation and warm regards from us to you,-Twister Fest Staff

story:
Background

I was Born in Frankfurt, Germany to a Colombian mother and Puerto Rican father, which at the time was stationed there with the US Army.

Soon after, I traveled to Puerto Rico, Miami and finally, at the age of 7, to live in Bogota, Colombia, were I grew up. 

The lack of opportunities and my unwillingness to conform pushed me to travel to the US to pursue my dream of becoming an artist.

 I use a vast array of non- conventional materials such as: pills, hair, bottle caps, chop sticks, etc. I take common objects out of their context and using different techniques, I transform them into art pieces.

In my subject matter, I focus on the social challenges such as human rights, spirituality, consumerism, recycling, etc.In addition to gallery showings, I have participated in international cultural exchanges, workshops and talks.  I am also an art handler for several local galleries, museums and have done interior design for commercial spaces and local restaurants.


90 Miles

Everything started with my connection and appreciation for Afro-Cuban music as well as the social situation of the Cuban people.These two aspects gave me the idea of making a piece with multiple colors and rhythm as I try to convey the many things immigrants had to leave because of the political and social violations being inflicted upon them from an abusive power.

It is impossible to live in Miami and not immerse one's self in Cuban culture and history. Personally, there is a particular quality that I admire, It is their sense of union.This deep rooted union inspired me to produce an art piece using 90 miles    of material which as we all know is the distance between Florida and Cuba.

90 miles is a contemporary crochet project created using yarn that spans the length of 90 miles. Consists of a single, continuous, multi- colored strip about 9 inches in width. The final piece will be about 2 miles long but the total amount of yarn used will equal 90 miles. It is an ongoing project, that I have already started,     so far I have completed the first 20 miles of material. 

This project's intention is to bring art closer to the spectator, to everyday life. It addresses subjects such as immigration and human rights that encourage the viewer to engage in an open discussion. 

90 miles involves the community and reflects their cooperation in the production of the artwork. Funds for the yarn have until now, been provided from the community.. 

As I work on completing the 90 miles, I am documenting the process of transformation through a series of “Actions.” Each action envelops an object or space by wrapping it with the yarn, allowing the viewer to see the piece evolve both in length and in color. These actions are documented with photographs. This documental part of the piece makes 90 miles temporary, as. each action exists only for the brief amount of time that it is being recorded. I value this documental process equally as important as the final result. 


Donations

Where will the money go? Is quite simple! 
All the donations will be used to get 150,000 yards of yarn that I need to
produce the 90 miles, printing and mailing fees.
 
What You Get

The basic donation will give the contributors the opportunity to be displayed on a list along with the final piece,  making them an essential component of the installation and its process of creation.

With the next level donation the contributors not only will be on the list but will also receive a print of any picture of the actions, please visit my gallery.  


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute, please share , spread the word 

using social media or the Indiegogo share tools.

If you are in Miami you can visit the MDC Museum of Art+Design located at the Freedom Tower on February 2015 where I will be installing the 90 miles.

Thank you for your support.

story:
Lightbox- What is it?

Lightbox is an emerging collaborative art space and social enterprise in the heart of Kampot, Cambodia. The creative space hosts exhibitions, creative workshops, artists in residence, screenings and performance. It provides opportunites to celebrate, learn and regenerate creative arts. As a social enterprise, Lightbox works to socially and financially support the community and its partners through its activities.

Currently, a group of student volunteers are developing a business model to turn Lightbox into an art bar. The space will serve the purpose of providing an opportunity for Khmer artists to showcase their work while immersing tourists in Cambodian culture.  When Lightbox becomes a sustainable business it will provide ongoing funding to Mayibuye Cambodia.

Mayibuye Cambodia is a not-for- profit organisation providing access to arts programs for  young people in rural areas. They aim to assist in helping regenerate traditional Cambodian arts and culture that were threatened as a result of the of the Khmer Rouge regime. Mayibuye Cambodia promotes self expression, creativity and confidence through the programs they run for over 400 children living in rural communities. These programs include performing arts classes with addtional classes in art and life skills. This facilitates educational opportunites and provides a place to talk freely about issues affecting young people, who are vulnerable to negative peer pressures and at risk behaviour. 

In Cambodia especially, including art and culture as part of a child's educational experience is a crucial gateway helping strengthen  cultural identity. 

What We Need 

We have identified that we will need $7921 in start up funds. This includes covering existing costs as well as funds to undertake the first 6 months of operation. These costs include:

  • $1382 - to repay existing interest free loan
  • $3539- to finance equipment and infrastructure improvements
  • $3000- to assist in offering job security for Lightbox staff for 6 months
Meeting our Goal of $8000 would enable Lightbox to begin operations and start making a positive social impact. Due to our lack of start up capital, relying on generous donations is vital to getting Lightbox up and running!

The Impact

Currently Mayibuye rely heavily on donations in order to continue providing their programs to the community. Our aim is to eliminate their dependence on donations by developing Lightbox into a successful hospitality business whose profits will provide an ongoing and sustainable source of funding for Mayibuye.

The difference Mayibuye makes to the lives of Cambodian children is priceless. Through increased access to contemporary and traditional arts in rural education systems, students are developing a new level of self expression and cultural enrichment.  

Risks & Challenges

We have conducted intensive market research and found significant gaps in the market and exciting opportunities to pursue.

Our in depth research has also highlighted the following challenges, which we will take into account in the development of Lightbox.

  • A number of social enterprises already exist in Kampot- However, Lightbox will be the only business that combines both a hospitality and an area specifcally for art collaborations
  • Lightbox is not situated on the main road, which includes many other bars and restaurants. However, the hidden location is part of the charm! 
  • Revenue is largely dependent on the tourist and expat community in Kampot, a certain amount of traffic will be needed to remain profitable. Word of mouth will be essential to ensure new people keep discovering Lightbox

Other Ways You Can Help

Monetary support isn't the only way you can support Lightbox! How about try some of the ideas below? They won't cost you a cent but are crucial to the success of our business. 

  • Tell your friends about our Indiegogo campaign and share it on your social media
  • 'Like' the Lightbox (Kampot, Cambodia) Facebook page
  • Check out our website and learn more about Lightbox and Mayibuye
  • Mention Lightbox to those you know travelling to Cambodia, we would love for them to pay us a visit!
  • Lend us your expertise! We are always looking for extra help and advice

story: The Fine Art & Art History class of 2015 are starting preparations for their final degree show. The exhibition will run from June 18th - 21st and will be the last stage in 3 years of hard work and learning. We want to make sure we put on the best show possible, and are fundraising to produce a catalogue as well as buy the paint, materials, and tools needed to get the exhibition space in top show condition.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Help SHIFT Magazine 

create its premier print publication  

SHIFT Magazine promotes creative community through print and presence. We hold gatherings and share our stories as LGBTQ visual artists, writers, and performers in the Seattle area. 
SHIFT was founded as a concept by local artist Carissa Meier who wished to build and bring together all of the above listed community attributes. 
The SHIFT Committee, a small group of Seattle based creatives, have received over 30 submissions for the first issue! The committee is so pleased to be a platform for these submissions. Now, we need your help to take the next step in sharing!
The true goal is to share with the community. With this said, we do not want to charge for the Magazine but we are accepting of donations to support the printing costs. We hope the cycle of community will bring together philanthropy and interest. We're asking for help to finance the print production costs for the magazine.  
Why print?  SHIFT seeks to connect people in real time and space.  Thus it is important for the magazine to be a tangible publication that can be seen, touched, smelled, bent, drawn on, read together, and passed on.    

What We Need & What You Get

  • SHIFT will cost roughly $1300 to print with other costs accrued. 
  • With this desire for support to print we have some heartfelt gifts to share as perks! *See PERKS section*
  • All donations will go to the cost of printing. Perks are all donated by members of the committee. 
Support given to SHIFT will increase connectedness within our LGBTQ community here in Seattle.

story:
WITH ONE LAST WEEK TO GO WE WANT TO THANK EVERYONE WHO HAS HELPED US TOWARDS OUR GOAL! 


PLEASE DONATE TODAY, AND HELP US LAUNCH PDA PRESS!


PDA PRESS 

We are about building art communities

We are about creating awareness of new art and artists 


OUR CAMPAIGN

Help PDA PRESS come to Life!

PDA Projects is a contemporary art gallery and we believe in being part of the amazing creative community of Canadian artists. We are always looking for new ways to showcase the making of art. All of our projects focus on art that challenges the status quo and invigorates new conversations. 

This is why we are publishing books.

PDA PRESS is the latest addition to PDA Projects and will focus on publishing limited edition books: 

  • Art books
  • Short stories
  • Graphic novels
  • Poetry
  • Critical essays on contemporary art

THE FIRST PUBLICATION: 

THE SAMENESS BETWEEN YOU & I 

EDITED BY: Bükem Reitmayer & Simon Honeyman

80 Pages
Perfect Bound
Printed on archival paper

THE SAMENESS BETWEEN YOU & I  is a collaborative publication that brings together 15 writers, poets, artists, and illustrators to create an artwork in its own right. 

This publication has been carefully curated by PDA Press and its editors Bükem Reitmayer and Simon Honeyman. This 80-page compilation of poems, photographic essays, short stories, and vibrant illustrations encompasses themes of loss when looking at gender and sexuality. 

CLICK HERE TO SEE ALL THE WRITERS' AND ARTISTS' BIOS! 


THE SECOND PUBLICATION: 

OLD MAN FASHIONISTA 

By GUILLERMO TREJO


50 Pages
4 x 4 Inch Miniature Book
Saddle Stitch
Printed on archival paper

OLD MAN FASHIONISTA, by Guillermo Trejo, is a photographic visual diary of one man who appreciates how older men respect the gravitas of hats. Guillermo Trejo documented old men wearing hats in public during his travels across North America over the past year using his iPhone and posted them onto Instagram. For Trejo, wearing a hat is not a random action—it is a consideration. Yes, these men choose their hats based on external conditions, be it hot or cold, rainy, snowy, or sunny. Yet these men also choose their hats to show their personalities in public. These men are participating in a generational tradition. Trejo states, "When I look at the old photographs of my late grandfather he was always wearing hats. My grandfather was a humble man. He was a construction worker who dressed well. I always loved him and his hats."

Samples from OLD MAN FASHIONISTA by Guillermo Trejo


ABOUT THE ARTIST: 

Guillermo Trejo is a Mexican artist based in Ottawa. He completed his BFA at the National School of Painting, Sculpture and Etching in Mexico City with a specialization in printmaking, and moved to Canada in 2007. The experience of immigration has shaped Trejo’s work. He holds an MFA from University of Ottawa and presented his Master’s thesis at the Ottawa Art Gallery. His first solo exhibition was at Saw Gallery (Ottawa), and he has been Artist-in-Residence at Creative Fusion (Cleveland). In addition, Trejo has worked as research consultant at the National Gallery of Canada, and he teaches printmaking at the Ottawa School of Art. 


THE THIRD PUBLICATION: 

STATES OF HOMES

By ALYSHA FARLING

50 Pages
Perfect Bound
Printed on archival paper

Alysha Farling's States of Homes is a curated account of her personal sketch books. She draws houses that are a direct reference to her larger installations. She gives agency to the homes by animating them as characters that play out narratives of drug abuse, sexual acts, and existential crisis. The artwork in this publication was created from 2013-2015. It is a firsthand account of how young artists create, question, and work through their practice.


Samples from STATES OF HOMES by Alysha Farling 

ABOUT THE ARTIST 

Fascinated with miniature worlds, Alysha Farling creates sculptural installations that create enchanted environments. Her installations reach out from the ceiling and the walls, expanding into the space of the gallery, featuring an arrangement of small connecting balls of dirt planets, inhabited by creatures at play. Her challenge is to relocate magic in the sculptures; Farling says, “as a kid, magic was easy to locate, but now I am finding it difficult...When I talk about magic I am also including the dark and the strange – the tingly, the scary and the unexplainable.” 


Guillermo Trejo using his Intaglio Press 


DETAILS OF THE PERKS:

PERKS WITH THE WOODCUT PRINT BY GUILLERMO TREJO: 

Guillermo Trejo, PDA Skull 2014, 15 x 20 Inches, Woodcut 


WHAT YOU GET FOR THE LIMITED EDITION PRINTS BY CARA TIERNEY
THE PDA POPSICLE PERK: 

Cara Tierney, Artsicle, 2011; 21.75 x 29.5 Inches, Digital Print Ed. 1/1


THE PDA MILE HIGH CLUB PERK:

Cara Tierney, Halifax Airport Sketch, 2012; 21.75 x 29.5 Inches, Digital Photographic Print

THE PRIMAVERA PERK:

Cara Tierney, Primavera, 2012; 21.75 x 29.5 Inches, Digital Photographic Print


THE BREAKDOWN:

Your donations will make an important contribution to support today's artists: 

We are campaigning to release our first three publications.  As a contributor your donations will have a long lasting impact for the artists. Your contribution will help us achieve our goal of continuing publications that represent new artists over the coming years. 

We have referenced and based our fundraising on current CARFAC rates. We also want to ensure the longevity of PDA PRESS.

  • We are raising $ 16,000. Your contributions will go towards paying the artists, editors, and writers. 
  • Your contributions will pay for media advisors and graphic designers involved. 
  • Your contributions will aid in publishing all three books. 
  • You will receive advance copies of the publications.
  • You will receive limited edition prints from Guillermo Trejo, and Cara Tierney. 

PDA x LOCAL

We are committed to keeping PDA Projects local. For us, the idea of being local is not just Ottawa. We think bigger: Local is all of Canada. 

We are a gathering space and PDA PRESS is building communities and long-lasting relationships. That is why we continue to work with Canadian businesses, such as Shopify, House of Barons, Lieutenant's Pump, Display Laminating, Evans Adrian International, and Blueprint Homes.

Donating to PDA PRESS is a contribution to all working artists in Canada. 


ADDITIONAL SHIPPING INFORMATION: 

International Shipping Rates Based on Perk and Location Per Book:

(please add these amounts to total pledge based on perk and location)

Canada: $10 | USA + Mexico: $14 | United Kingdom + Rest of Eurasia: $16 | Australia: $18 | Japan: $20 | Everywhere Else: $24



THE ORIGIN STORY


ABOUT THE PDA PROJECTS TEAM

PDA PROJECTS director Brendan A. de Montigny met former co-founder Meredith Snider at the University of Ottawa during their Masters of Fine Arts. Both de Montigny and Snider have worked as practicing artists, educators, and either in commercial galleries, or artist-run centres. They came together in 2014 out of a similar passion to open a project space. Also, they both appreciate alliterations. Snider left PDA Projects in the summer of 2015 to follow he artistic career. Brendan still wears pink shirts, and the odd bow-tie, put's on exhibitions, and publishes books.  
 

PDA PROJECTS GALLERY

PDA Projects is an art gallery that currently represents 8 artists, and we invite other artists, and curators to exhibit solo or group shows. 

PDA PRESS 

The reason we are reaching out to you today. Come be a part of PDA PRESS!


ABOUT BRENDAN A. de MONTIGNY: 
I hold a DEC from Heritage College, a BFA from Concordia in Painting & Drawing with a minor in Print Media, and a MFA from the University of Ottawa. 

In my own artistic practice and research, I work within large performative installations, painting and drawing. I am interested in the ideas of decay/ruins, utopias, science fiction, subcultures (Punk-metal-hardcore), and comic books. My artwork has been seen at the AGO, Todmorden Mills Museum, in Montreal, New York State, Ottawa City Hall Art Gallery, and Drain Magazine. 

I have also guest lectured at Carleton University, the University of Ottawa, and have been a sessional professor at Algonquin College. Prior to PDA Projects, I worked in commercial galleries such as Galerie LeRoyer (MTL), Galerie de Bellefeuille (MTL), and Galerie St-Laurent + Hill (OT). I am also an art consultant with Canada Council for the Arts.

story:
The Testimony

In 2002 circumstances steered me to Independence Hall where I worked as an armed guard assigned to protect Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell.

There were many posts, but on this day I was posted in the courtyard of Independence Hall. It was a beautiful sunshiny day when the visitors were taking in the history before them when the distinct, crackling sound of something falling overtook the visitors, and me, and we all did stop to see what was falling. A large limb from one of the trees fell majestically to the ground.

Initially, while recognizing this as a unique experience, I failed to see the divinity in it. Then, several days later, someone made a reference about the felled limb. It was then that a voice came unto me as clear as the ringing of the Liberty Bell on July 4, 1776. It is my belief that it was the Holy Spirit that said "It's historical. Go out there and get some of it." And so I did just that.

By this time the large limb had been cut into sections, making it possible for me to lift.

Later on I had an arborist meet me at Independence Hall to examine the limb, and identify the parent tree, its age, and species. The aborist's report states "There is only one Tree-of-Heaven in the vicinity of where the tree fell."

I remain faithful that this is a wonderful blessing from the Lord, however there is no greater blessing than His Son Jesus Christ, whom without Him none of this is possible.


The side clock of Independence Hall


The steeple of Independence Hall


The Syng Inkstand used by Thomas Jefferson when he drafted the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.


Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell are the most significant historical icons in all of the United States.  Independence Hall is where the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution were signed, and celebrated with the ringing of the Liberty Bell on July 4, 1776.

My goal is to recapture the moment in history when our country was born by creating a historical exhibit that includes representations of the greatest significance.  My overall objective is to create a display of great historical value and aesthetic appeal that will educate and delight viewers across the country, both children and adults.

The architecturally accurate scale model was the most difficult and expensive feature to complete, however there is still a lot of work to be done.  For example, within this exhibit will be 4-6 brass and metal lampposts equipped with LED lighting, replicated to the likeness of the lampposts of that era.  Lighting will emanate from the lampposts.  The landscaping will be set in actual miniature cobblestone.  

The Liberty Bell, like Independence Hall, will also be highly detailed. 

Also, in addition to the sterling silver replica of the inkstand used by Thomas Jefferson and the Signers, will be framed copies of the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.  These documents will hang above the model of Independence Hall, in direct relationship with the inkstand with which they were drafted, and the historical building where they were signed.

I want to create an exhibit that will travel to cities throughout the country, giving all Americans a chance to experience this very special history.

Historical Preservation

The Historical Tree will add life to the exhibit, giving the viewers something authentic to admire, while preserving the current landscaping of Independence Hall forever.

Projected Completion Date

This project has no time constraints.  Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell has a history that will never be erased, and with this exhibit I intend to honor that history well into the future.  Once I receive the requested funding, the final phase of constructing the exhibit to completion will take approximately 2-3 months.

Risks and Challenges

The most difficult obstacle in creating this exhibit has already been overcome with the construction of the model. It required me to take architecture courses and collaborate with the best scale model architect in the Philadelphia area. It took me painstaking hours to draft the intricate details that are featured above.

Now, it's time to bring this project to completion!
story_txt:
The TestimonyIn 2002 circumstances steered me to Independence Hall where I worked as an armed guard assigned to protect Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell.There were many posts, but on this day I was posted in the courtyard of Independence Hall. It was a beautiful sunshiny day when the visitors were taking in the history before them when the distinct, crackling sound of something falling overtook the visitors, and me, and we all did stop to see what was falling. A large limb from one of the trees fell majestically to the ground.Initially, while recognizing this as a unique experience, I failed to see the divinity in it. Then, several days later, someone made a reference about the felled limb. It was then that a voice came unto me as clear as the ringing of the Liberty Bell on July 4, 1776. It is my belief that it was the Holy Spirit that said "It's historical. Go out there and get some of it." And so I did just that.By this time the large limb had been cut into sections, making it possible for me to lift.Later on I had an arborist meet me at Independence Hall to examine the limb, and identify the parent tree, its age, and species. The aborist's report states "There is only one Tree-of-Heaven in the vicinity of where the tree fell."I remain faithful that this is a wonderful blessing from the Lord, however there is no greater blessing than His Son Jesus Christ, whom without Him none of this is possible.The side clock of Independence Hall

story:
The Belize Sea Goddess is an exciting new living sculpture in the sea project

The Marine Foundation  is  excited  to launch the creation of  a new living sculpture in the sea with  sculptor Toin Adams.  We  have been approached by Captain Norian Lamb who represents the Dangriga fisherfolk from the Long Caye region  in Belize to initiate a new underwater gallery commencing with the installation of the Belize Sea Goddess. 

A large   Marine Protected Area  has recently been set-up and terminated their traditional fishing rights  which means they have lost their entire livelihood almost overnight.  They understand the need for protected areas but the reality is, how do they  earn a living when  their only practical knowledge and experience is of the sea which is their only resource? The plan is to create a dive site to which the fishermen can bring tourists and tell their story which will educate and spread awareness of the importance of caring for our natural resources whilst simultaneously creating a conscious and sustainable way for them to survive. The Marine Foundation is addressing this same problem with traditional fishing communities all over the world.  (For more details on our other projects and how this is done please visit www.themarinefoundation.org) But to do this we are seeking your support.

Belize  is a multi-ethnic nation whose major influences are  Mayan, Creole/Kriol, Garinagu (Garifuna -African)  as well as Latino / Spanish. Toin and Celia will draw on these rich and varied cultural roots to design an inspiring sea goddess. The sculpture  will be  created with the help of local artisans and fisherfolk to be sunk and positioned  in the stunning Belize sea. This process will galvanise their environmental effort as well as a way  for education  and raising of awareness.   The Goddess will  serve as a protector to the coral and all that live under the waves. The sculpture will not only look visually stunning but  provide habitat for fish and marine life.  The Belize Underwater Goddess will be the  first in a program of underwater artworks for the region.

The Marine Foundation has successfully installed a number of sculptures in Indonesia;  Apsara was our most recent artwork sunk in east Bali in October where we have established the Jemeluk Bay Underwater Gallery with the local fishing community and Reef Check Indonesia. We created a short mood film  after our previous successful crowd-funder with Indiegogo.  You can watch   Apsara spirits of the sea. You can see the team and hear about their experience with the making of .

In June 2011, The Marine Foundation  installed the Coral Goddess in Pemuteran, an award winning coral restoration project where the local community have managed to restore their local reef and bring it back to life, creating a thriving Eco-tourism destination.       

We are also being joined on our trip by Louisa Harris. Louisa first joined the Marine Foundation in October 2014  as a model and freediver for the sinking and filming of Apsara;Spirits of the Sea. She is now part of our Core Creative Team. When she is not a busy sea nymph Louisa is a sustainability consultant in London. She specialises in innovative and experiential ways to engage individuals and businesses with the Sustainability agenda and creative solutions to complex problems. Currently she is working with Grant Thornton UK and 6Heads a collective dedicated to shared learning within Sustainability and innovation. She is also an aerialist who brings performance elements to The Marine Foundation’s work and brings a new dynamic of human, ocean relations to the visuals we produce.

The Marine Foundation is  thrilled to be taking its work to a new continent and are really keen to ask for your support. Together we can make a stunning work of art and help a community make a vital transition to becoming guardians of their marine treasures. We all benefit knowing we are putting in place innovative practices that will improve and maintain the health of our sea for  all future generations. Please donate or help spread the word. 

We are working to a tight timeframe; presently Toin and I working on the designs and organising the preparation for our arrival in Belize in mid May. The work will be created and installed during our 2 week stay. We have an amazing team and we are thrilled to invite you on this extra-ordinary journey.

Donations will support the travel, expenses and creation of the Belize Underwater Goddess and the initiation of the under water gallery. This campaign will effect lives locally as well as generating amazing imagery that will promote a sustainable and creative relationship with our marine treasures around the world.

story:
About Me and my Campaign


Hello, my name is Adrien C. Tucker. I've been making and selling paintings since 1995 when I was 19. My style is all over the board from portraits, to abstracts, to landscapes and cartoons. 

I have set up my campaign to raise money for me to take a couple weeks off of my week to week job and post 500 of my original paintings on Etsy.com. I would also like to use the funds to promote my Etsy.com page, my website, and my facebook art page. 

This would be huge! I never seem to have the time and energy needed to photograph my art, edit the photos, and post them to Etsy.com along with descriptions etc. Having 500 more paintings for sale should help free up some time to actually make new art instead of house painting 40 - 60 hours a week! I really hope this jumpstarts my career and my life in a wonderfully new direction.


Contributions


I am hoping to raise $2,000. 

Two hundred dollars will go to update my website. I would like to add 85 new pictures and a bio.

Two hundred dollars will go towards promoting my website, my facebook art page, and my Etsy.com page. 

Each listing on Etsy.com costs twenty cents, so one hundred dollars will go toward that. 

Five hundred dollars will go to shipping out perks, which I estimate about $5 each for shipping one hundred perks. 

One thousand dollars will go toward my living expenses for the two weeks it will take me to achieve my goal. 


Perks!


My perks are great! For donating only $20 you will receive an original Hatguy painting on canvas that I make just for you! My hatguy character, that has been around since 1995, is well loved by my art fans and friends alike. 

If by some chance I don't make my goal of $2,000, your contribution will certainly still go towards my posting art, promoting, etc. Everyone that contributes will get the perk that I promise, no matter how few contribute. I appreciate every one of you. Thanks. :)


For me


As an artist, I have a great desire for my work to be seen, touched, and tasted. This campaign does just that, and in many ways. If I am able to start making money from the hundreds of paintings that I already have, I will be able to make more new paintings and keep the flow going. That's all I want. I am very excited for the work I have not made yet. I hope you enjoy my art and also look forward to what will come from my studio in the future. 


Risks or Challenges


There's nothing too risky nor too challenging in this particular campaign. The only thing that will prevent me from achieving my goal would be an awful sickness, injury , or my death. I will take lots of photos, edit and crop them in photoshop so that they accurately portray the art. Then I will post these paintings on Etsy.com. A good friend does my website and helps out with promotion. I will promote my facebook page and add photos to it myself.


Other Ways You Can Help


Forwarding my campaign on social media will be a great big help. Please venture to check out my website, AdrienCTucker.com, my Etsy.com page, and my facebook art page. 
Another great way to help would be to buy my art. I have around 50 works on Etsy.com right now! Thank you so so much. :)

Sincerely, 
Adrien C. Tucker

story:
What is the Vault?
Located in a 12,000 sq ft space in a former bank building in Tuscola IL, The Vault Arts Collective is home to over 70 artists, providing something unexpected in Central IL. We are just 25 minutes south of Champaign/Urbana and the University of Illinois and 30 minutes north of Eastern Illinois University in Charleston. We have free monthly events featuring art shows/exhibits and live music from local and touring musicians. (Check out the Gallery tab above for a photo tour of The Vault)

What is AMP?
We want to keep bringing more new music to you, as well as help promote the great independent musicians out there. AMP is our plan to achieve that and more.

Anchored by a 3 month concert series and an Indiegogo fund-raising effort, with your help, we can continue and expand our space for musicians to showcase and grow their talents.

Our Goals:

  • Upgrade the Vault’s Stage and Sound System
  • Provide Space for Open Mic Nights, Classes, Jam Sessions
  • Promote Independent Music Artists
  • Fund Future Live Music Guests

We are also opening a Record Store!
Led by our friends at Cavetone Records, Sound Bank will feature vinyl, art and more! Sound Bank will also offer subscription based vinyl curating services to help you discover the best in new independent music, as well as hand-picked classics.

"What do I get out of this?"
Maybe the next Elvis, Kurt or Janis will grace the stage at the Vault? This is your chance to be a part of history and know that you helped make it happen. (OK, maybe we are overstating it a little ;) If we can provide a space for musicians like we have done for visual artists, and we can help them grow their audience, then we will have succeeded.

We'd never just ask for a handout if we didn't have something to offer! We've put together some awesome perks, including limited edition artwork, Vault and AMP event merch, plus some great bonuses from our sponsors! (Everybody gets sumthin')

Here are some of the perks you can get for supporting our project:

Buttons & Stickers
 

AMP Series Posters (9.75" x 17")

Sound Bank T-shirt

Limited Edition Bracelet by Cynical Redhead

Limited Edition Pick Necklace by Karl Jendry

Limited Edition AMP Signed Art Print by Zac Atkinson



Come to our concert series and check out all the Vault has to offer!

Thank You to our AMP Project launch sponsors:

http://cavetonerecords.com

http://gossadvertising.com

http://shopvintagekarma.com

http://infinautgames.com

story:
The idea behind Zooplankton is that science and art are a lot more connected to one another than we often think. Project Lead, Becca Priddy, is a science and theatre teacher in Portland, Oregon-

"As an educator who teaches in both realms of art and science I am often confronted with the curiosities of the middle ground that these subjects cover. It is here where we as scientific artists lie. It is in this same place that I often find myself in conversations, my brain being picked as some sort of oddity. How can one person be both scientifically and artistically inclined? 

The original drawing by Ernst Haeckel
I want to build and bring Zooplankton to life at Burning Man, as my own radical self expression.  Zooplankton will bring our community together, it will be a place of art to learn about science, to express ourselves artistically, and to see what others have discovered before us. It brings together art and science, as well as the past and the present. The Zooplankton team in Portland is already hard at work planning this project for all of us out there with a curious mind."
Actual size Radiolarian (or what we're calling Zooplankton)

Zooplankton will be a 20 foot tall shady space for everyone to relax and enjoy. During the day Zooplankton will be a classroom where guests from the community will hold classes and workshops on science and other topics. By night the 150 acrylic spikes attached to the shell of Zooplankton will illuminate in a dazzling bioluminescent spectacle! Our programmer, Tony, has been hard at work developing a way to connect these spikes to a thermal camera that will be placed inside Zooplankton, sensing body heat.

Tony is developing the LEDs and acrylic spikes.

 The more people who join the fun inside, the more bizarre, interesting, and exciting the light show outside. Zooplankton will be a place to dance, meet new friends, and watch lights dance around a 100,000:1 scale replica of an ancient ocean organism.  

Why Does Zooplankton Cost So Much?

Although we are already working with the community to find tools to borrow for free, communal space to use, and the entire project is being built by volunteers, we still need to pay for all of the materials to build Zooplankton.

$3,400 will go towards building the structure:

  • 132 pieces of lumber and 53 pieces of plywood for the structure
  • Screws, nuts, bolts, drill bits, and other hardware
  • Gasoline for our generator at night all week so that the bioluminescence lighting can run all night long, and you can feast your eyes.
  • Industrial ground screws to keep Zooplankton secure to the ground 
  • Custom hardware and brackets
  • Pyrotechnics! Who doesn't love that?
$5,100 will go towards our awesome bioluminescence and lighting effects:
  • 175 multi color LEDs with state-of-the-art "nodes" to make the light show fancy and fun!
  • Individually programmable LED strips to line the top of the beacon, to lure wanderers into Zooplankton, the way that an anglerfish lures prey! Nom.
  • Dust proofing, to keep our bioluminescence playa-free
  • An Arduino to control the spikes
  • Wiring to convert AC to DC power in several places on Zooplankton
  • The infrared camera to sense bodies inside! 
  • Over 300 feet of wiring so Zooplankton can get its groove on
  • 175 clear acrylic spikes


What if we raise extra money?

We have some really great ideas for stretch goals, some of them include:
- Creating plexiglass windows to fill some Zooplankton's holes with Ernst Haeckel's art, laser etched onto them, lit by LEDs at night, and programmed with the rest of the LED spikes! 
- Displaying a microscope that projects images of real radiolarian fossils onto the walls inside of Zooplankton! Is that possible? Probably. Anything is possible! 

Why your donation matters:

Zooplankton has been created from our imagination as a project for the community by the community.

Zooplankton crew working on the design!
We cannot make it to Burning Man without this campaign
We have held one small fundraiser in Portland in order to raise just enough funds to for our build lead, Landon, to buy materials to begin building parts of the top section of Zooplankton to take to our regional burn, but without this funding, we will not be able to bring Zooplankton to completion.

We are also applying for other art grants regionally in hopes to raise additional money we know that this project will require. We are doing our best to use every avenue possible to raise money. 

In addition, we are being fiscally sponsored by Dusty Visions, a local Burner-run 501(c)3 whose mission is to create and support community driven and Burner inspired art, events and education. We are honored to be sponsored by Dusty Visions, whose founding board members led Portland C.O.R.E projects in 2011 and 2012, as well as supported other art projects locally, on playa and in

ternationally. Teaming up with DV allows your donation to be tax deductible. 

Awesome perks include (but are not limited to):

This awesome bandana designed by Pantsless Santa! Available in multiple colors.

Nifty Zooplankton Stickers! Designed by Sarah Erratica! 

(one of multiple designs)


The infamous Burner Spirit Animal Poster by Sarah Erratica 

(one of three designs)

A sweet Refrigerator magnet designed and made by hand by Sarah Erratica. Your choice of a round magnet with one of three Zooplankton logos, or a square magnet with your Burner Spirit Animal.


Challenges

Although Dusty Visions has completed major projects before, this is Becca Priddy's first Burning Man project. This is also the first major project for a handful of volunteers working on Zooplankton. We have confidence that by working with Dusty Visions we will be guided in the right direction, gain knowledge that only people who have done this before know, and will ultimately succeed with this project. Our main challenges include 

  • Raising enough money to build Zooplankton! 
  • Programming Zooplankton's bioluminescence from scratch
  • Building a 20 foot structure with volunteers in four months


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that sometimes contributing can be difficult:

  • Every dollar helps! No amount is too small to help us get to Burning Man!
  • Share this campaign with your friends, share on Facebook, Twitter, or other social media. 

Thank you for helping Zooplankton make it home.
story_txt:
The idea behind Zooplankton is that science and art are a lot more connected to one another than we often think. Project Lead, Becca Priddy, is a science and theatre teacher in Portland, Oregon-

"As an educator who teaches in both realms of art and science I am often confronted with the curiosities of the middle ground that these subjects cover. It is here where we as scientific artists lie. It is in this same place that I often find myself in conversations, my brain being picked as some sort of oddity. How can one person be both scientifically and artistically inclined? 

The original drawing by Ernst Haeckel
I want to build and bring Zooplankton to life at Burning Man, as my own radical self expression.  Zooplankton will bring our community together, it will be a place of art to learn about science, to express ourselves artistically, and to see what others have discovered before us. It brings together art and science, as well as the past and the present. The Zooplankton team in Portland is already hard at work planning this project for all of us out there with a curious mind."


Actual size Radiolarian (or what we're calling Zooplankton)
Zooplankton will be a 20 foot tall shady space for everyone to relax and enjoy. During the day Zooplankton will be a classroom where guests from the community will hold classes and workshops on science and other topics. By night the 150 acrylic spikes attached to the shell of Zooplankton will illuminate in a dazzling bioluminescent spectacle! Our programmer, Tony, has been hard at work developing a way to connect these spikes to a thermal camera that will be placed inside Zooplankton, sensing body heat.


Tony is developing the LEDs and acrylic spikes.
 The more people who join the fun inside, the more bizarre, interesting, and exciting the light show outside. Zooplankton will be a place to dance, meet new friends, and watch lights dance around a 100,000:1 scale replica of an ancient ocean organism.  

Why Does Zooplankton Cost So Much?
Although we are already working with the community to find tools to borrow for free, communal space to use, and the entire project is being built by volunteers, we still need to pay for all of the materials to build Zooplankton.
$3,400 will go towards building the structure:
 132 pieces of lumber and 53 pieces of plywood for the structure
Screws, nuts, bolts, drill bits, and other hardware
Gasoline for our generator at night all week so that the bioluminescence lighting can run all night long, and you can feast your eyes.
Industrial ground screws to keep Zooplankton secure to the ground 
Custom hardware and brackets
Pyrotechnics! Who doesn't love that?


$5,100 will go towards our awesome bioluminescence and lighting effects:

175 multi color LEDs with state-of-the-art "nodes" to make the light show fancy and fun!
Individually programmable LED strips to line the top of the beacon, to lure wanderers into Zooplankton, the way that an anglerfish lures prey! Nom.
Dust proofing, to keep our bioluminescence playa-free
An Arduino to control the spikes
Wiring to convert AC to DC power in several places on Zooplankton
The infrared camera to sense bodies inside! 
Over 300 feet of wiring so Zooplankton can get its groove on
175 clear acrylic spikes
   
What if we raise extra money?
We have some really great ideas for stretch goals, some of them include:
- Creating plexiglass windows to fill some Zooplankton's holes with Ernst Haeckel's art, laser etched onto them, lit by LEDs at night, and programmed with the rest of the LED spikes! 

- Displaying a microscope that projects images of real radiolarian fossils onto the walls inside of Zooplankton! Is that possible? Probably. Anything is possible! 

Why your donation matters: Zooplankton has been created from our imagination as a project for the community by the community.

Zooplankton crew working on the design!
We cannot make it to Burning Man without this campaign
We have held one small fundraiser in Portland in order to raise just enough funds to for our build lead, Landon, to buy materials to begin building parts of the top section of Zooplankton to take to our regional burn, but without this funding, we will not be able to bring Zooplankton to completion.

We are also applying for other art grants regionally in hopes to raise additional money we know that this project will require. We are doing our best to use every avenue possible to raise money. 
In addition, we are being fiscally sponsored by Dusty Visions, a local Burner-run 501(c)3 whose mission is to create and support community driven and Burner inspired art, events and education. We are honored to be sponsored by Dusty Visions, whose founding board members led Portland C.O.R.E projects in 2011 and 2012, as well as supported other art projects locally, on playa and in
ternationally. Teaming up with DV allows your donation to be tax deductible. 
Awesome perks include (but are not limited to):


This awesome bandana designed by Pantsless Santa! Available in multiple colors.


Nifty Zooplankton Stickers! Designed by Sarah Erratica! 
(one of multiple designs)



The infamous Burner Spirit Animal Poster by Sarah Erratica 
(one of three designs) 



A sweet Refrigerator magnet designed and made by hand by Sarah Erratica. Your choice of a round magnet with one of three Zooplankton logos, or a square magnet with your Burner Spirit Animal.


Challenges Although Dusty Visions has completed major projects before, this is Becca Priddy's first Burning Man project. This is also the first major project for a handful of volunteers working on Zooplankton. We have confidence that by working with Dusty Visions we will be guided in the right direction, gain knowledge that only people who have done this before know, and will ultimately succeed with this project. Our main challenges include   Raising enough money to build Zooplankton!  Programming Zooplankton's bioluminescence from scratch
Building a 20 foot structure with volunteers in four months
   
Other Ways You Can Help We understand that sometimes contributing can be difficult:  Every dollar helps! No amount is too small to help us get to Burning Man! Share this campaign with your friends, share on Facebook, Twitter, or other social media.    Thank you for helping Zooplankton make it home.

story:
Short Summary

Help us bring the work of Minnesota artist Jim Denomie to Friedrichshafen, Germany to exhibit at the new artist-run project space ProjekTraum.

ProjekTraum: l'Atelier Glidden Wozniak is a project space in the studio of visual artist Felicia Glidden and musician Alain Wozniak. They met at the artist residency Salem2Salem in 2010. In 2014 they bought a store front  in Manzell, Friedrichshafen and have converted it into a live-work space. They have collaborated on several projects as ProjekTraum, and the exhibition by Jim Denomie will be the first exhibition to take place in their studio.

"Artist Jim Denomie depicts politics, history and contemporary Native American issues using bold colors, big brush strokes and a heavy dose of satire. He earned a degree in studio arts and Native American studies from the University of Minnesota, and began painting the world around him. A visual storyteller, his work enlightens and educates people, and is in collections all over the world. " from PRX 10,000 voices

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising money to help cover costs for the exhibition Jim Denomie: Paintings which will take place in Friedrichshafen Germany September 27 -October 25, 2015.

Costs include: 

  • Translation of catalog essay from English to German $300
  • Shipping                                                                                            $400
  • Catalogue Printing                                                                       $400
  • Postcards/Posters                                                                          $75
  • Postage for Postcards                                                                 $200
  • Art Historian Fee (to speak at the opening reception)  $300
  • Opening Reception (food and beverages):                         $200

                                     Total                                                                $1875.00

We are asking you to support this effort of artists working with artists!

Here are images of some of the rewards for donating.
See Perks on the right side of the page for more details:

Edward Curtis, Paparazzi-Skinny Dip,  etching  11x14 inches signed by the artist and dated 2009

Casino Sunrise, etching  11x14 signed by the artist and dated 2009

"Angel" linoleum cut (7 x 5 inches) prints signed by the artist and dated 2002
 

cast iron acorns by Felicia Glidden, cast in 2007 in Minnesota

More about ProjekTraum l'Atelier Glidden Wozniak

Felicia Glidden (b. 1966 USA) is a visual artists who works in many diffferent media (video, painting, sculpture) to reveal that which is hidden and just below the surface. Much of her inspiration comes from dreams (Traum in German.) She grew up in north Minneapolis, Minnesota and after earning her BFA in Fine Art and Art History she lived in northern MN where she ran Minoan Painting, a restoration painting company. In Duluth, she  was a member of Common Language, a non profit arts organization which created opportunities for artists to work together.  She later worked as the education coordinator at Franconia Sculpture Park.  Felicia went to graduate school in 2009 at the University of Maryland in the Washington DC area and upon graduating (MFA Studio Art 2012) moved to Germany to join her husband Alain Wozniak. She is  currently teaching part time at the Jugendkustschule Bodenseekreis.

Alain Wozniak (b. 1958 France) is a musician (clarinet) and a conductor for symphonic wind orchestras.(in Germany and Switzerland). He was the principal clarinet for the Theater des Westens Berlin for 20 years before moving to Friedrichshafen to begin teaching and conducting.  His first degree is in electronics  from University of Science and Technology in Villeneuve d’ Asq, France, he went on to study music in Berlin Hochschule der Künste, Berlin, and earned his third degree in conducting at the Conservatory of Feldkirch, Austria.  He is versed in Classical, Jazz and improvisation. He is fluent in French, German and English.

Since they met in 2010, Glidden and Wozniak have collaborated on three large projects: En Route, video 2011 NY, ProjekTraum Wasserwerks  live music and three channel video installation inside of a cement water reservoir 2014, CH, and most recently Prometheus 2015: symphony for light and video installation by Philippe Wozniak (Alain's oldest son,) with the Symphonic Jugendblasorchester Friedrichshafen, conducted by Wozniak, with a live video composition by  Glidden. Alain was also invited to play his orginal compositions inside of a sculpture sound installation by Felicia called Between Two Rivers lll at Galerie Bagnato for Kunstnacht Konstanz 2015.

Glidden and Wozniak are interested in inviting international artists to create solo exhibitions in their atelier in Manzell, Friedrichshafen.  They plan on hosting three or four exhibitions in a year at ProjekTraum. Felicia is fundraising, organizing and operating the project space. 

Felicia and Alain at ProjekTraum the day signed a purchase agreement Feb 2013

Please see the gallery for more pictures of ProjekTraum l'Atelier Glidden Wozniak in construciton and as a working studio.


Why Jim Denomie?

Jim Denomie (B 1955 Wisconisin, USA) is a painter who confronts issues about United States History and Native American History head on in his narrative paintings.  He uses humor, art history and contempory events as threads through brightly colored dreamscapes and landscapes.  His work widely collected and are included in these notable museums:
  • Denver Art Museum
  • Eiteljorg Museum of American Indians and Western Art, Indianapolis
  • Evergreen State College, Olympia, Washington
  • Hallie Ford Museum of Art, Willamette University, Salem, Oregon
  • Heard Museum of Native Cultures and Art, Phoenix, Arizona
  • Minneapolis Institute of Arts
  • Minnesota History Center, St. Paul
  • Minnesota Museum of American Art, St. Paul
  • Montana Museum of Art and Culture, Missoula
  • Philbrook Museum of Art, Tulsa, Oklahoma
  • Science Museum of Minnesota, St. Paul
  • Tweed Museum of Art, Duluth, Minnesota
  • Weisman Art Museum, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis
  • Westphalian Museum of Natural History, Munster, Germany

Felicia Glidden is interested in helping Denomie broaden his audience in Europe. They both grew up in Minneapolis, Minnesota and bringing him to Friedrichshafen for the premier of her project space is a way of grounding herself in her new home in Germany.  Glidden never imagined she would be living in the south of Germany (or she would have studied the language much sooner), but somehow, moving to Europe is teaching her more about what it means to be an American. Jim Denomie's work is rooted in this American experience, in ways that reflect contemporary society and reach back into history with truth and humor.

Jim Denomie 1/1 monoprint from Untruthful Series 2011  at Bockley Gallery

Here is the website for Jim Denomie
You can find more information about Jim Denomie on his Wikipedia page
He is represented by Bockley Gallery in Minneapolis

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Tell everyone!! If you are unable to contribute financially, please spread the word through your online network!

    Any money raised above the goal will go toward airline tickets and travel expenses for artist Jim Denomie.

    In the event we don't reach our fundraising goals, the money would be first dedicated to translation costs, then the catalog printing and next shipping fees.

story:
I have been running a metaphysical and new age shop for over a decade and reading tarot for over two decades. I have been expanding into lenormand and am looking forward to publishing my very own lenormand deck based on my love of Tudor history.
Creating a deck is the easiest part. Where we need your help is in getting the publishing part of things up and going. We want to be able to offer high quality cards and quality packaging for each deck while still staying affordable.
Lenormand is one of the fastest growing forms of cartomancy out there (in terms of popularity) and a good deck must have specific aspects that make it "readable". We are looking to bring the beauty of Tudor England to the amazing energy of Lenormand.

The completed deck will be smaller than regular Tarot Cards, (the size of Poker cards) in a plastic box. The Deck consists of 36 Cards. There are the traditional 36 Cards of the Lenormand system in the basic deck, and the Special Edition comes with a second Man and Woman Card option.

At this time we are working on a PDF version of the "little white book" so that we can offer more information and features then a traditional LWB.

The challenge for me is my location in rural New Mexcio, and how that impacts my ability to find quality partners to bring my vision to life.

Where is the money going?

Here is a breakdown of how the money that we raise through this campaign will be spent. This is the closest approximation we have for the campaign. Once we reach the stretch goals everything gets done faster and more goodies can come your way!

  • 80% of the Funds will go to the Printing, Delivery and Import of the Decks
  • 10% of the Funds will go to the Designer for the Box and the Booklet
  • 10% of the Funds will go to Indiegogo to process the campaign

Stretch Goals

  • $3, 500 - Limited Edition Run of Larger Sized Cards in Collectible Tin
  • $5, 000 – Full Companion Book: This will be a robust and lovely illustrated book with so many goodies in it! Along with the Card meanings and how to read them, it will also feature spreads.  We'll throw some great Tudor history for you too! The funding will be used to get the book edited professionally, contribute to the cover design, printing, shipping, taxes, etc. The book will be completed by early 2016

  •   ALL BACKERS WILL GET THEIR PERKS regardless of if we meet goal or not!
Can't share financially? That's OK - you can help us by spreading the word to your friends and around the web. Every set of eyes that sees our campaign could be a potential investor!

Thank you for your support - we look forward to unveiling some teaser images very soon! Pictures will be posted in the Gallery tab above as well as on our Pinterest board at www.pinterest.com/rdapothocary

story:
Sound Births Creation

Is an interactive Underwater Sound Art installation where the audience is immersed in a Deep Listening experience of embodying Music in water.
Hello everyone!

We are Bethan and Gabe, who are Artists and Musicians hear to bring a magical underwater Listening experience to the world. The whole idea for the project began when Bethan created an Interactive Art installation for her final year degree show at University, using frequencies in water when listened to with the Body. Bethan was fascinated with the Creation principles of Fetal Listening, and how we initially come into our Life surrounded by water, listening within the Womb.

To re-create this immersive atmosphere of listening from within the body through water. We have been co-creating a Sonic journey, woven with sounds of the natural elements, the Human voice, Crystal singing bowls and other therapeutic instruments to compose an organic musical journey to take Listener's deep into the realm of embodied Sound. 

Our dream is to raise funds to purchase some Underwater speakers to make this water Sound-bath happen in physicality. We have everything else in place, the Music, the instruments, the bodies and the swimming pool space. Now all we need is this last piece of equipment to make this vision a reality!

We are raising the funds to purchase the Underwater speakers to put up this installation this coming September, under the natural Light of the Stars in an outdoor swimming pool. This first instalment will allow us to explore further into the realms of underwater sound, then we hope to create other interactive Live performances and Sound Art installations both in America and the UK.

By donating any amount to us, it will all go to purchasing the equipment to act as a platform for this life-long musical exploration to continue and expand into something beyond our dreams. I imagine one day to also bring this medium of underwater Listening to the process of Water Births, so when babies are born into the world, they can be born through the essence of Sound and Music. 
I feel like my life long exploration and background in both Visual Art and Music has been leading up to this project, and now its finally time for it to be born!

We are offering some great perks to give back to You if you feel guided to contribute, You can also own and listen to the album yourself once it has been recorded and send you an electronic copy of the Music. We are also offering some personal customised Art just for you from Bethan ! And a personal piece of Music composed just for you by Gabe! You can even have the opportunity to come and experience this for yourself and be immersed in the magical realm of underwater music.
Everything we raise hear will go 100% to the Speakers for the installation, we have already invested time and money in all the other instruments and equipment.

This project could go so far into the future and benefit the way in which we Listen as Human Beings - through the Body. The material of Sound in water is truly spectacular and an experience I wish everyone to feel for themselves - our core intention is to to expand the very Art form of our relationship with Sound and experience of Music.

We would be eternally grateful if you could support this Art and Sound project to make the magic happen and even if you are just interested in the type of Music and Art we create, please do get in touch and share this project with your friends!
Thank You so Much!
Bethan and Gabe,
'Allow the Sound,  be With You'
For more Information please contact:
bethaneriverafay@gmail.com
Our Art and Music
https://elvenstarlightart.wordpress.com/
https://soundcloud.com/elviea
https://soundcloud.com/new_humans

Bethan and Gabe,
'Allow the Sound,  be With You'
For more Information please contact:
bethaneriverafay@gmail.com
Our Art and Music
https://elvenstarlightart.wordpress.com/

https://soundcloud.com/elviea

https://soundcloud.com/new_humans

story:
Brief introduction

My name is Eric van Straaten. Full color 3D printing is my trade. I am in need of my own full color 3D printer to gain a higher degree of esthetical quality, as every artist in search of perfection.

Even though having a lot of opportunities to show my work, due to the very high production costs, I am still struggling as an artist. Each sculpture leaving my studio, has to be funded by myself. Because the printer is not always consistent in quality, it may happen that a sculpture has to be printed several times. Also during the finishing of a sculpture a lot may go wrong. Pieces may break, the surface may be damaged, etc. You can imagine the production cost sometimes surmounts the sales price. If you could help me to get my own printer, I will be able to reduce those costs.

This is why I am looking for sponsors to help me to get a full color 3D printer of my own. As a thank you for sponsors, I have created a range of limited editioned 3D printed figurines that can only be found in this campaign. For further information about the printer I need and why that costs $60.000, scroll down below the description of the perks.

WHAT DO YOU GET FOR YOUR SPONSORSHIP?

Keep in mind that full color 3D printing at this level takes a lot longer than you would expect. Especially the post processing is time consuming as you can see in the video at the top of this page. Time will also be needed to get my own machine up and running. Even if I do not reach my goal, you will still receive the perk you ordered!

NOTE: To order, click on a 'perk' at the right upper corner of this page or below the description underneath. Then, check in as a guest or create an Indiegogo account. Payment is only possible by credit card or with PayPal. If you are not able to do either, I can help you. Go here: CROWDFUNDING VOOR NEDERLANDSE SPONSORS

$1 - Share This Page and Win! Refer as many friends as you can to this campaign and convince them to sponsor me. When their contributions have totalled at least $500, you will receive a free Humbelle figurine "Supersoaker". Height: 9 centimeters. If you want to count as a referrer, you must share this campaign with the share tools on this page while logged in to your own Indiegogo account. You also have to be a sponsor to join this contest. For people who are not able to choose one of the other perks, I have made the special "Share This Page and Win!" perk of $1. This is important because otherwise, your unique ID will not be attached to any resulting contributions or visits. Click here to order

$10 - The 3D Printing Helpdesk on my website is a (secret) place where you can ask 3D printing related questions. Having experimented and worked for 6 years, I have acquired a lot of knowhow, especially in making digital models 'print ready'. For only $10 you will have unlimited access to all I know about full color 3D printing. Click here to order

$15 - A set of 5 unique postcards depicting surreal scenes. A special coupon code is included. With this code you get a 50% discount in my web shop at www.ericvanstraaten.com. Shipment included. Estimated delivery: August 2016. Click here to order

$50 - Extra small Humbelle Figurine "Onesie". Limited edition of 200. Height: 6 centimeters. Shipment not included. Estimated delivery: Before Christmas 2016;) Click here to order

$25 - Extra small Humbelle Figurine "Princess Pug" - Onesie is happier if you get her friend "Princess Pug" too. Limited edition of 300. Height: 4 centimeters. Shipment not included. Estimated delivery: Before Christmas 2016;) Click here to order

$35 - Extra small Humbelle Figurine "Peli" - Onesie is happiest if you get her friend "Peli" too. Limited edition of 300. Height: 5 centimeters. Shipment not included. Estimated delivery: Before Christmas 2016;) Click here to order

$100 - Bulk order discount on Onesie and her two friends. 100 available (normal price $110). Shipment not included. Estimated delivery: Before Christmas 2016;) Click here to order

$100 - Small Humbelle Figurine "Chucks". Limited edition of 100. Height: 8 centimeters. Shipment not included. Estimated delivery: Before Christmas 2016;) Click here to order

$150 - Medium Humbelle Figurine "Supersoaker". Limited edition of 65. Height: 9 centimeters. Shipment not included. Estimated delivery: Before Christmas 2016;) Click here to order

$175 - Medium Humbelle Figurine "Kitten". Limited edition of 40. Width: 9 centimeters. Shipment not included. Estimated delivery: Before Christmas 2016;) Click here to order

$250 - Large Humbelle Figurine "Humming". Limited edition of 35. Height: 12.5 centimeters. Shipment not included. Estimated delivery: Before Christmas 2016;) Click here to order

$300 - Extra Large Humbelle Figurine "Rabbit". Limited edition of 30. Height: 15 centimeters. Shipment not included. Estimated delivery: Before Christmas 2016;) Click here to order

$400 - Extra Large Humbelle Figurine "Angry Mermaid". Limited edition of 25. Height: 15 centimeters. Shipment not included. Estimated delivery: Before Christmas 2016;) Click here to order

$500 - Giant Humbelle Figurine "Pug". Limited edition of 20. Height: 17.5 centimeters. Shipment not included. Estimated delivery: Before Christmas 2016;) Click here to order

$1.750 - Bulk order discount on all 10 Figurines. Limited edition of 10 (normal price $1.985). Shipment not included. Estimated delivery: Before Christmas 2016;). Click here to order

MORE INFORMATION ABOUT ME AND THE CAMPAIGN

Biography

Born in 1969 I grew up and am still living and working in Haarlem, The Netherlands. I used to sculpt my detailed statues by hand. Six years ago I began to master the art of 3D modelling. Within a year I was able to produce my first 3D printed sculpture. Soon my work was picked up by several known galleries and collectors. At this very moment my sculptures are in high demand with galleries in the Netherlands, Belgium, France, USA and Japan. To my great honor, my sculpture ‘Pelican’ is featured on the ‘Lucas Museum of Narrative Art’s’ website as a representative example of work that will be exhibited as a part of the collection. Check it out here: http://www.lucasmuseum.org/collection/category/digital-sculpture-01.html

The largest 3D printed sculpture I ever made, assembled in 15 parts

About the full color 3D printer

The only 3D printer that in my opinion is able to produce beautiful 3D prints in full color, is the ProJet by 3D Systems (formerly known as ZCorp). The printer large enough for my sculptures, is the ProJet 650. This machine is not a DIY desktop printer, but an industrial machine that does not come cheap. Even a second hand one, suitable for my sculptures, would cost around $40.000. Furthermore the print materials are very expensive. Color and binder cartridges are about $1.000 and the machine has to be fed with print medium (a kind of plaster) at a cost of $6.000. Cartridges and print medium have to be resupplied regularly as you start printing.

The 3D printer I want to buy, underneath this mountain of powder is one of my 3D printed sculptures

Why the ProJet 650?

I believe there is no other technique that can achieve the level of hypersurrealism made possible in 3D computer modelling. Industrial 3D printing is the only technique that can be used to make full color digital models tangible, close to the original design. I aim for physical expressiveness in my sculptures, while preserving a certain digital feel. It has been said my sculptures contain a weirdly eroticized corporeality, although the models are completely virtual. Like Barbie, they will never be real human, nor will they be based on a real human. They are a complete figment of my imagination. Balancing on the edge of kitsch, the marzipan-like quality of the ProJet material resonates beautifully with the apparent innocence of the scenery.

The software that feeds the printer. Here a model in parts called "Leda" is sent to the 3D printer

Why do I need your help?

Even though having a lot of opportunities to show my work, due to the very high production costs, I am still struggling as an artist. Each sculpture leaving my studio, has to be funded by myself. Because the ProJet is not always consistent in quality, it may happen that a sculpture has to be printed several times. Also during the finishing of a sculpture a lot may go wrong. Pieces may break, the surface may be damaged, etc. You can imagine the production cost sometimes surmounts the sales price. If you could help me to get my own printer, I will be able to reduce those costs because no third party is involved.

After printing and cleaning, the 3D printed parts need to sit in a bath to make them water resistant and brighten the colors

Join the experience

To my knowledge, I am the only artist in the world working at this level of full color 3D printing. Your donorship would therefore be part of an unique experience! To make that experience a real one: I have created a Helpdesk on my website, a (secret) place where you can ask 3D printing related questions. Having experimented and worked for 6 years, I have acquired a lot of knowhow, especially in making digital models 'print ready'.

The finished 3D printed sculpture "Leda" in my studio (70 cm high)

Risks and Challenges

To reach my goal, including the production costs for the perks of this crowdfunding campaign, I have estimated that I need around $60.000. This is a serious lot of money, but I am confident that I can bring this money to good use and it will provide me with the opportunity to further develop my work. As sponsor, you carry no risk at all: even if the campaign does not reach its target, you will receive the perks you have chosen. Any amount will help me, so do not hesitate to contribute! Thank you in advance, Eric van Straaten.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the word out and share my campaign amongst you friends! You can also befriend me on Twitter (https://twitter.com/ericvanstraaten), Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/ericvanstraatendotcom/) and Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/ericvanstraaten). My accounts are private due to the sensitive nature of some of my work, but if you befriend me, I will accept you. Also please use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Melody Cooper: A Rare Diamond Shining

My name is Melody and I was born and raised in SC and currently live in NYC.  I am campaigning to raise funds to record an EP in a studio as production is costly.  As a teacher, I also work with children and students with disabilities and  include music therapy to inspire and encourage all learners.  I plan to record and perform globally and I am getting started by singing on stages in NYC, in classrooms as well as on social media platforms.  I spend a great deal of time learning about music and marketing as well as developing my repertoire.  I aim to include studio recording to solidify my goals  and  seek an opportunity to put it all on wax and to record and distribute my music.  Please help support my creative endeavors through this Extended play/mixtape project.  I am currently attempting to raise 1000.00 to supplement production, engineering  and material expenses to create a quality musical product to share with everyone.

The Impact

I have performed throughout my life in musical plays, in children's theater, on all county choir programs, spoken word underground productions, Karaoke, open mic nights, gospel choirs, graduation programs, mock broadway performance at broadway revue, etc.  The funding to support my music would help me to extend beyond live performances, to share with more people and to develop more professionally as an artist.

Risks & Challenges

As a mother, teacher, and recent graduate I have overcome many obstacles in life.  I have focused on developing in other disciplines and although I always included creative projects, I have faced challenges with focusing solely on my artistic aspirations .  I have used my voice for the "voiceless" in hospitals,  academic settings, faith based spaces, and everywhere I go.  I plan to direct my focus on this project and continue moving in that direction to follow my vision and dreams with music.
Other Ways You Can Help 
Encouragement and support in several ways helps even if you are not in the position to contribute financially at this time.  Please visit my youtube channel and subscribe and comment on my videos (Melody Cooper).   Stay tuned so that you can visit  me and support other artistic projects and in future endeavors.  I always feel inspired when I see family, friends, subscribers and supporters in general listed and commenting on pages that I create.
Thank you for supporting my project..I trust that all things will work out for the best because I BELIEVE that Dreams come true!
